attributes.title: Matching and Weighting for Observational Component of Summer Bridge Program Evaluation

q1.value: Matching and Weighting for Observational Component of Summer Bridge Program Evaluation

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Background: we are hoping to evaluate the effects of a summer bridge program on student outcomes. Rationale for the present part of the analysis: in order to identify the effects of the program, we hope to match students invited to the summer bridge program with students who have a similar propensity of an invitation but who were not invited. We will use the results to weight the data to better estimate the causal effect.

q16.value: In this part of the analysis, we are not testing hypotheses. Instead, we are exploring whether there is overlap between students invited to the summer bridge program and students not invited on observed covariates, and if we can use this overlap to evaluate the causal effects of the program.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses using the following approach: 1. First, we will estimate a model that predicts a student's invitation status to summer bridge 2. Then, using the scores from step one, we will use the covariate balancing propensity score (CBPS) method to match and weight observations

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The goal of the study is to test how the perceived authority of Intergovernmental Organizations (IGOs) depends upon features such as their decision-making processes, the inclusiveness of their membership, their levels of technical expertise, and the extent of their interactions with civil society.

q16.value: H1: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the policy recommendations resulted from a consensus-based decision making process. H2: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when policy recommendations resulted from a process that involves consultation with civil society. H3: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the organization has a reputation for technical expertise. H4: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the organization has an inclusive membership base.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: The goal of the study is to test how the perceived authority of Intergovernmental Organizations (IGOs) depends upon features such as their decision-making processes, the inclusiveness of their membership, their levels of technical expertise, and the extent of their interactions with civil society.
registration_responses.q16: H1: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the policy recommendations resulted from a consensus-based decision making process. H2: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when policy recommendations resulted from a process that involves consultation with civil society. H3: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the organization has a reputation for technical expertise. H4: Recommendations made by Intergovernmental Organizations will be perceived as more authoritative when the organization has an inclusive membership base.

attributes.title: To Steal, or Not to Steal: Attitudes towards Electricity Theft in Northern India

q1.value: To Steal, or Not to Steal: Attitudes towards Electricity Theft in Northern India

q2.value: Jason Chun Yu Wong | Brian Blankenship

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: There is strong evidence that proper electricity access brings about positive impacts in income and well-being. Chakravorty, Pelli, and Ural Marchand (2014) found that rural household incomes increased significantly with legal grid connections, and this increase was even more significant with higher quality electricity with less outages. Ahmad, Mathai, and Parayil (2014) found significant positive relationships between electricity access and health and education attainment in both rural and urban settings. While improving electricity access and quality brings about positive welfare changes, India, as the second most populous and fastest growing economy, still does not have reliable energy data, posing difficulties in identifying sources of electricity supply problems and in designing effective reform policies (Rai et al., 2017). Aklin et al. (2015) showed that such policy failures have significant impacts on the rural population’s attitudes towards government and their voting choices. The primary motivation for this project is to study public opinions and attitudes towards elec- tricity theft. Power theft is rampant and a serious problem in many countries - in both developing and developed countries (Lewis, 2015). It is estimated that electricity theft constitutes 20-25% of the generated power in India - a cost of INR 20,000 crores annually (Sharma et al., 2016; Gaur and Gupta, 2016). Theft of electricity occurs in several forms, including illegal tapping (using katiya), consumer meter tampering, and through billing problems (irregularities with billing or unpaid bills) (Sharma et al., 2016). Existing policies have failed to curb electricity theft and remains a focus of the new Saubhagya scheme. This survey provides a timely study of public opinions towards electricity theft in order to inform policy design that could generate better public buy-in.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 (Income and theft acceptability). The income level of an individual using katiya is negatively related to social acceptability and positively related to the desired punishment levels. Hypothesis 2 (Supply quality and theft acceptability). The electricity quality level of an indi- vidual using katiya is negatively related to social acceptability and positively related to the desired punishment levels. Hypothesis 3 (Caste, religion, and theft acceptability). Theft is more socially acceptable with the Dalit caste and less acceptable for persons of different religious background (than one’s own). Hypothesis 4 (Theft versus Other Crimes). Stealing from family, friends, and strangers is less acceptable than stealing electricity. Hypothesis 5 (Supply quality and billing). Respondents are more likely to choose the billing plan with higher promised electricity supply quality (i.e. longer total hours supplied). Hypothesis 6 (Charges and billing). Respondents are more likely to choose the billing plan with lower charges.

q17.value: In the conjoint scenarios, respondents are given four pairs of persons to compare. Each scenario presented has two person’s characteristics, including possibly differing covariate dimensions. Respondents are asked to choose whether person A or B is less acceptable, or about the same. Thus, the outcome is an ordered variable representing the latent distribution of relative social acceptability of the activities of these persons presented. Respondents are also then asked for the appropriate punishment level, in in- creasing severity levels from a small fine, a hefty fine, to jail time. This is also an ordinal outcome variable representing the latent distribution of punishment severity desired for the less acceptable hypothetical person. In a separate section, billing scenarios are also presented to respondents with varying dimensions, where total hours of electricity supplied, base charges, and tariffs differ. Plan A is always a pre-paid method and Plan B always a post-paid, varying in the electricity supply quality dimensions as well as charges. The recorded outcome variable is binary choice between A and B, thus measuring the propensity one would choose a pre-paid over post-paid plans given the other dimensions.

attributes.title: Government investment in R&D and Politicians’ Popularity

q1.value: Government investment in R&D and Politicians’ Popularity

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Many governments direct a substantial share of GDP towards R&D expenditures. However, such investments typically pay off with substantial lag (for example, in medicine the average time lag between a scientific finding and its implementation is 17 years). Unlike other long term government investments (such as infrastructure projects) they are not directly observed by citizens, and so are unlikely to contribute to incumbent’s popularity. This contributes to political economy puzzle: why do incumbents invest substantial funds in projects that do not help them to secure their office, but will most likely pay off when their successor is in power, given their budget constraint. One potential explanation of incumbent’s willingness to support innovation is that he may be willing to invest in R&D in order to (1) raise his popularity by signalling his competence to voters or to (2) provide anticipation of future economic benefits for citizens. Contrary to this argument, I expect that pro-R&D policies do not benefit politicians’ popularity. In order to test these hypotheses, I conduct survey experiment in Russia and USA, where I present respondents with random vignettes stating that an incumbent invested heavily in R&D, education, and infrastructure, and short-term innovation. I then ask respondents to indicate the level of their support for the incumbent, their assessment of his competence and the economic expectations, should his policy succeed. I expect pro-R&D incumbent to get less favourable assessment from citizens.

q16.value: Assumong pro-R&D politician is coded as Treatment, while all other types are coded as Control, I can formulate 4 groups of hypotheses, where all hypotheses can be evaluated using two available measurements: difference in scores of Treatment and Control politicians and scores from forced choice. I plan to use difference in scores measurement and use the forced choice score as a robustness check. • H1a-c (in each country): Respondents are less likely to indicate that they support Pro-R&D politician for a new term, compared to Control Politician, where Control denote Pro-Education; Pro-Infrastructure and Pro-Short-term innovation; H2a-c (in each country): Respondents are less likely to rate Pro-R&D politician as more competent, compared to Control Politician, where Control dedote Pro-Education; Pro-Infrastructure and Pro-Short-term innovation; • H3a-c (in each country): Respondents are less likely to have greater economic expectationd from Pro-R&D politician’s policy, compared to Control Politician’s, where Control dedote Pro-Education; Pro-Infrastructure and Pro-Short-term innovation; • H4a-k: The results of the survey are the same in USA and Russia. Hence, there are 54 hypotheses that could be tested, assuming no heterogeneous treatment effects within a country. The Bonferroni multiple correction on all of them would create too conservative p-values. Thus, I will select primary hypotheses to be H1a, H2a, H3a and H4a (respondents’ choices for supporting politician for the second term between pro-R&D and Education politician do not differ between Russia and USA). I will test all other hypotheses using the methodology of Positive False Discovery Rate testing. However, since I expect to get negative significant results, I will re-code the test accordingly, so that nFDR would be the expected quantity defined by the number of false negative results, divided by the number of significant features conditional there is at least one significant results: nFDR = E[F |S < 0]. I will present uncorrected and S FDR-corrected results as a robustness check.

q17.value: The main specification will be paired t-tests. OLS with covariates would be performed as a robustness check H1 will be confirmend if there are negative treatment effects for pro-R&D politician on stated voter support for politician in the second term. H2 will be confirmend if there are negative treatment effects for pro-R&D politician on competence perceptions. H3 will be confirmend if there are negative treatment effects for pro-R&D politician on economic expectations.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The goal of this project is to determine what effect, if any, U.S. statements of support for the Syrian opposition had on protest mobilization during the 2011 Syrian Revolution. I use an online survey of Syrian activists to measure activists perceptions about foreign support, their protest behavior, and a battery of other demographic and political variables that may condition such an effect. I also include a survey experiment designed to explore what information activists use to form their expectations for foreign support (third party public statements, past behavior of third parties, and/or the balance of power).

q16.value: Mobilization H1 (participation): individuals that anticipate foreign support are more willing to join protest movements than those who do not H2 (severity): individuals that anticipate foreign support are less likely to anticipate extreme repression than those who do not H3 (duration): individuals that anticipate foreign support expect protest movements to succeed more rapidly than those who do not Forming Expectations H4 (cheap talk): public statements of support significantly increase dissidents’ expectations for foreign support H5 (costly signals): costly responses to recent, similar uprisings significantly increase dissidents’ expectations for foreign support, to a greater degree than public statements.

q17.value: My data source is an online survey among Syrian activists' social networks. It is a non-probability sample targeted at Syrian activists and their similar peers, who together constitute a target population of "plausible protesters." The survey permits two types of analyses. The first is examining basic descriptive statistics about the Syrian activist population, along with the relationship between nonviolent or violent opposition behavior and respondents' expectations for foreign engagement. While the sample is not nationally representative of Syrians, it should allow me to characterize beliefs among the activist community and some of their close peers who did not choose to protest. Second, the experimental component permits a causal investigation of the determinants of respondents' beliefs about foreign support.

attributes.title: The Importance of Retributive Justice under Uncertainty

q1.value: The Importance of Retributive Justice under Uncertainty

q2.value: Paige Bollen | Lily Tsai | Jon Mellon | Tiago Peixoto | Johannes Hemker

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Under what conditions are individuals more likely to value retributive justice? Combining a large-scale survey experiment that tests the causal effect of priming individuals to think about agencies that punish government officials that misuse government funds on their attitudes toward taxation with novel machine learning techniques, we evaluate the moderating effect of social and economic uncertainty on the strength of the retributive justice prime. Specifically, we use advanced quantitative methods to explore variation in the strength of the retributive justice treatment effect, training causal forests to parametrically estimate features of the conditional average treatment effects across a battery of country-level characteristics.

q16.value: We hypothesize that economic and/or social uncertainty is associated with larger treatment effects for the retributive justice treatment. Specifically, we argue that economic and social uncertainty makes people more likely to value government as a provider of moral and social order and punishment that upholds order. People in contexts with relatively higher uncertainty are thus more likely to express willingness to pay taxes when reminded about the strength of top-down channels for anti-corruption. Specifically, we have two primary hypotheses: 1) Individuals in countries with relatively higher levels of economic uncertainty are more likely to have higher estimated conditional average treatment effects; and 2) Individuals in countries with relatively higher levels of social uncertainty are more likely to have higher estimated conditional average treatment effects. Our independent and dependent variables come from the original tax morale survey (already described in another Pre-Analysis Plan). We combine these data with country-level data from a variety of sources, relying primarily on data from the World Bank and the Quality of Governance dataset (Teorell et al., 2019). The survey data collected a limited amount of individual-level data, so our analysis primarily focuses on exploring heterogeneity across country-level covariates that capture economic uncertainty, social uncertainty, and other country-level characteristics that are common controls, but unrelated to uncertainty.

q17.value: We test our hypotheses about heterogeneous treatment effects as a result of uncertainty using two recent machine learning approaches. We start by implementing a nonparametric causal forest to estimate which variables are the most important for predicting heterogeneous treatment effects (Wager and Athey, 2018). We measure variable importance by looking at the reported by the grf package (Athey and Wager, 2018) “variable importance” score for each covariate included in the causal forest. The variable importance measure reported by the grf package is based upon a count of the proportion of splits on the variable of interest, weighting these proportions by the depth of the tree where the split occurs, with partitions occurring at lower depths receiving a lower weight. We predict that variables related to economic and social uncertainty will have higher variable importance scores. We then cross-validate this approach by using the recent method outlined by Chernozhukov et al. (2018), which focuses on using the random forest algorithm (Friedman et al., 2009) consisting of a large number of Classificaiton and Regression Trees (CART) (Breiman et al., 1984) to estimate features of the Conditional Average Treatment Effect (CATE) rather than the CATE itself because it relaxes many of the required assumptions. We focus specifically on estimating the individual-specific conditional average treatment effects, grouping those individuals into quintiles based on their predicted conditional average treatment effect, and then taking the difference in means of the included covariates between those in the highest and lowest quintile of predicted conditional average treatment effects. Under our hypotheses, we would expect the difference in means of covariates that are associated with social and economic uncertainty to be statistically significant from zero between those in the highest and lowest quintiles.

attributes.title: Incentives for Preventive Health Care Provision: Evidence from Brazil

q1.value: Incentives for Preventive Health Care Provision: Evidence from Brazil

q5.value: New York University; Rebecca Morton (NYU - IRB Sponsor);

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The recent Zika virus epidemic in Brazil warns the world about the dangers of tropical virus diseases. Although countries are investing in vaccines and other treatments, specialists agree that controlling the Aedes Aegypti mosquitoes is the most effective public policy intervention against the diseases spread by the mosquito (Eisen et al., 2009). This requires health care providers working within communities, helping residents to detect and eliminate the places where the mosquitoes may breed. Thus, the means by which these health workers are incentivized becomes crucial for their performance. This experiment investigates what are the optimal combinations of incentives that ameliorate the impact of these health care interventions. It is widely accepted that better incentives improve performance (Banerjee and Duflo, 2012). However, the optimal types and combinations of rewards have been contested. Some scholars argue that monetary compensation plus extensive monitoring foster efficiency (Duflo et al., 2012). Others, studying peer lending, posit that monitoring is also key to cope with moral hazard problems (Cason et al. 2012). Furthermore, few papers studied how to incentivize teams of workers, instead of individuals. As a result, health care workers are offered suboptimal incentives, sometimes in the form of flat salaries or, in the best-case scenarios, individual bonuses, neglecting teamwork. Frequently, these workers are not even properly monitored to ensure that they are doing their jobs efficiently, something virtually costless in the information era. This experiment proposes to remedy this gap, studying how different incentives work together in the Brazilian case. It will consist of hired and trained teams of subjects to perform a simplified version of the preventive care team’s job. These workers have to visit households informing them about dangers of the Aedes Aegypti. If allowed by residents, they will enter the house and search for potential breeding sites. Workers will receive two types of treatments: first, I will assign monetary bonuses rewarding their performances; second, I will inform a randomly selected group that they will be actively monitored using a cell phone technology developed for the research. Performance will be measured using the subjects’ reports of potential infestation sites detected in each household visited, GPS and other cell phone positioning data, post-treatment surveys, and municipal medical reports of diseases related with the Aedes Aegypti during the six months following the intervention. Ultimately, this research will contribute to understand how intrinsic and extrinsic motivation work in the case of interventions performed by teams. Moreover, it will be adding to an increasing political economy literature that studies how to incentivize teams, vis-à-vis individual incentives; and how subjects are affected by extrinsic motivations within these teams.

q16.value: I have five main hypotheses on the results, based on the literature and on the field experience acquired during my field visits in Brazil: H1. When compared with matched non-treated households, any form of intervention is better than no intervention. H2. The ordering of bonus performance is Peer Bonuses are better than Individual Bonuses, which are better than Control (Random Bonuses). H3. The knowledge regarding monitoring makes the pairs to comply more with the rules and have few attempt to cheat in self-reported outcomes, such as number of visited households. H4. When interacting active monitoring and monetary incentives, the performance on self reported decreases, but the quality of the intervention, in terms of time allotted per household, number of focus detected, and information transmitted to the households H5. The residual impact of the research starts to vanish one to two months, keeping all else constant, A. Aegypti prevention remaining constant.

q17.value: Using field experiment conducted in Rio Verde, State of Goias, Brazil. The main outcomes measured are: - Workers Level: number of breeding sites found per worker; reports by households (post-treatment survey); reports by supervisors; GPS data; the number of steps took once inside the household and household inspected area (from cell phone GPS and accelerometer). - Pair Level: number of visited households; the number of households that accessed the informational webpage; and number of households that allowed access to their premises. - Household Level: the survey on knowledge regarding the Aedes Aegypti (treatment and control households); resident evaluation of the worker's performance; municipal health data with the incidence of Aedes Aegypti discriminated by address.

registration_responses.q1: Incentives for Preventive Health Care Provision: Evidence from Brazil
registration_responses.q5: New York University; Rebecca Morton (NYU - IRB Sponsor);
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: The recent Zika virus epidemic in Brazil warns the world about the dangers of tropical virus diseases. Although countries are investing in vaccines and other treatments, specialists agree that controlling the Aedes Aegypti mosquitoes is the most effective public policy intervention against the diseases spread by the mosquito (Eisen et al., 2009). This requires health care providers working within communities, helping residents to detect and eliminate the places where the mosquitoes may breed. Thus, the means by which these health workers are incentivized becomes crucial for their performance. This experiment investigates what are the optimal combinations of incentives that ameliorate the impact of these health care interventions. It is widely accepted that better incentives improve performance (Banerjee and Duflo, 2012). However, the optimal types and combinations of rewards have been contested. Some scholars argue that monetary compensation plus extensive monitoring foster efficiency (Duflo et al., 2012). Others, studying peer lending, posit that monitoring is also key to cope with moral hazard problems (Cason et al. 2012). Furthermore, few papers studied how to incentivize teams of workers, instead of individuals. As a result, health care workers are offered suboptimal incentives, sometimes in the form of flat salaries or, in the best-case scenarios, individual bonuses, neglecting teamwork. Frequently, these workers are not even properly monitored to ensure that they are doing their jobs efficiently, something virtually costless in the information era. This experiment proposes to remedy this gap, studying how different incentives work together in the Brazilian case. It will consist of hired and trained teams of subjects to perform a simplified version of the preventive care team’s job. These workers have to visit households informing them about dangers of the Aedes Aegypti. If allowed by residents, they will enter the house and search for potential breeding sites. Workers will receive two types of treatments: first, I will assign monetary bonuses rewarding their performances; second, I will inform a randomly selected group that they will be actively monitored using a cell phone technology developed for the research. Performance will be measured using the subjects’ reports of potential infestation sites detected in each household visited, GPS and other cell phone positioning data, post-treatment surveys, and municipal medical reports of diseases related with the Aedes Aegypti during the six months following the intervention. Ultimately, this research will contribute to understand how intrinsic and extrinsic motivation work in the case of interventions performed by teams. Moreover, it will be adding to an increasing political economy literature that studies how to incentivize teams, vis-à-vis individual incentives; and how subjects are affected by extrinsic motivations within these teams.
registration_responses.q16: I have five main hypotheses on the results, based on the literature and on the field experience acquired during my field visits in Brazil: H1. When compared with matched non-treated households, any form of intervention is better than no intervention. H2. The ordering of bonus performance is Peer Bonuses are better than Individual Bonuses, which are better than Control (Random Bonuses). H3. The knowledge regarding monitoring makes the pairs to comply more with the rules and have few attempt to cheat in self-reported outcomes, such as number of visited households. H4. When interacting active monitoring and monetary incentives, the performance on self reported decreases, but the quality of the intervention, in terms of time allotted per household, number of focus detected, and information transmitted to the households H5. The residual impact of the research starts to vanish one to two months, keeping all else constant, A. Aegypti prevention remaining constant.
registration_responses.q17: Using field experiment conducted in Rio Verde, State of Goias, Brazil. The main outcomes measured are: - Workers Level: number of breeding sites found per worker; reports by households (post-treatment survey); reports by supervisors; GPS data; the number of steps took once inside the household and household inspected area (from cell phone GPS and accelerometer). - Pair Level: number of visited households; the number of households that accessed the informational webpage; and number of households that allowed access to their premises. - Household Level: the survey on knowledge regarding the Aedes Aegypti (treatment and control households); resident evaluation of the worker's performance; municipal health data with the incidence of Aedes Aegypti discriminated by address.

attributes.title: Elected Officials' Strategies for Targeting Voters

q1.value: Elected Officials' Strategies for Targeting Voters

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study addresses one of the fundamental areas of exploration within political science: how elected officials vary campaign targeting strategies across voters in their constituency. It has been long theorized that poor and rich voters receive different appeals, as do urban and rural voters. Poor, rural voters may be more responsive to clientelist appeals, whereas rich, urban voters may value public goods more highly. Poor voters may also be more sensitive to the immediacy of benefits, whereas rich voters may have longer time horizons. This area of exploration is particularly compelling in the continent of Africa, where co-ethnicity between the official and voter is thought to be a dominant predictor of vote choice.

q16.value: 1a. Politicians will target poor voters with more clientelistic appeals than they use for rich voters. 1b. Politicians will target rich voters with more programmatic appeals than they use for poor voters. 2a. Politicians will target rural voters with more clientelistic appeals than they use for urban voters. 2b. Politicians will target urban voters with more programmatic appeals than they use for rural voters. 3a. Politicians will target poor voters with threats at higher rates than they do for rich voters. 3b. Politicians will target rural voters with threats at higher rates than they do for urban voters. 4a. Politicians will use negative political advertising more for rich as compared to poor voters. 4b. Politicians will use negative political advertising more for urban as compared to rural voters.

q17.value: We compile a database of contact information for sitting elected legislators from 11 African countries, and recruit them to participate in a survey experiment over Qualtrics. The experiment presents a vignette describing a hypothetical voter that randomly assigns the poor/rich status and urban/rural location of the voter, and then inquires which strategy the politician would use to solicit the voter's vote.

q18.value: Ghana, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mauritius, Namibia, Nigeria, Rwanda, Seychelles, South Africa, Tanzania

registration_responses.q18: Ghana, Kenya, Liberia, Malawi, Mauritius, Namibia, Nigeria, Rwanda, Seychelles, South Africa, Tanzania

q5.value: Harvard: Mind Brain Behavior Initiative, Foundations of Human Behavior, Project on Negotiation, Institute for Quantitative Social Science, Center for American Political Studies

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Empirical deliberative democracy experiments have amply demonstrated that deliberation can increase political knowledge (Fishkin and Luskin, 2005; List et al, 2003) and political sophistication (Gastil and Dillard, 1999; Druckman and Nelson, 2003), but they have not causally identified deliberation itself as the causal mechanism. This is largely due to control groups that insufficiently control for all the characteristics of a deliberative body that might plausibly affect experimental subjects, such as audience monitoring, sunk costs, listening to and being heard by others, etc. But there is good reason to think that even if these deliberative components are present in a control group that the effects of the deliberation would still obtain relative to that group. Claus Scharmer theorizes that conversations come in two general forms: explicit knowledge conversations where participants ask and answer questions and aggregate their knowledge, and implicit knowledge conversations where participants deliberate and brainstorm and generate new knowledge (Scharmer, 2001). Scharmer's theory suggests that implicit knowledge conversations are more sophisticated than explicit knowledge conversations, and further that the more sophisticated the form of communication, the more sophisticated the participants become. As such, I propose a novel control group for a deliberative conversation: a question and answer (Q&A) session. A Q&A session can control for the aforementioned components of deliberation while still varying on what should theoretically matter as deliberation relates to political sophistication: the form of conversation itself. This study will thus measure the empirical effects of deliberation against both an information packet (which is a standard practice) as well as a Q&A session to discover whether conversation sophistication itself matters, or whether it's some other component of the deliberative process. This study will also compare other commonly-measured variables regarding deliberation such as efficacy (Morrell, 2005), trust (Cobb, 2011), and other communications questions (Gastil, 2014), etc.

q16.value: H1: Q&A participants will have greater knowledge gains over deliberative participants, but both will increase relative to participants who only read an information packet H2: Deliberative participants will have greater sophistication gains over Q&A participants, and only the deliberative group will show an increase overall H3: Deliberative participants will have greater gains in internal and external political efficacy than Q&A participants, and only the deliberative group will show an increase overall H4: Deliberative participants will have greater trust (in others and government) over Q&A participants, but both will increase relative to the information packet group H5: Deliberative participants will have greater openness to listening to others over Q&A participants, and only the deliberative group will show an increase overall

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested in a lab experiment at the Harvard Decision Science Laboratory (HDSL). Using HDSL's subject pool, this study will assign subjects into either a deliberative treatment or a question and answer (Q&A) treatment group, and within each assignment some subjects will be randomly assigned to join an information packet only group, or to the discussion group. These decisions are based on constraints of the lab (it's only large enough to run one group at a time). All three groups (deliberative, Q&A, and information packet) will share the following procedures. They will all answer a pre-test survey that measures their knowledge and sophistication about a political topic (minimum wage law), their internal and external political efficacy, and their level of generalized trust (toward others and the US government). Then each session will read the exact same information packet, a 12-page document created by a research assistant trained to be an expert in minimum wage law and theory. After reading the packet, the information packet group will then answer post-test survey questions which include the exact same questions as the pre-test, and also ask questions about demographics. In the deliberative and Q&A treatment groups, immediately after reading the information packet subjects will be exposed to 1.5-2 hours of either a Q&A session with the trained expert on minimum wage law, or a deliberative session where the expert is also present. There are two main differences between the two treatment groups. First, in the Q&A session subjects are only allowed to ask questions of the expert and to receive answers; they are not allowed to ask questions of each other. Second, in the deliberative session, subjects are allowed to express opinions in addition to asking questions, and they are only allowed to ask questions in the Q&A group. There will also be a moderator for both of these discussion groups, but the moderator's only tasks are to remind people to stay on topic, to provide opportunity for the expert to answer questions without interruption by informing subjects to allow the expert to answer, to remind subjects of rules when necessary, such as not to use their cell phones to look up information, and to remind people to consult their notepads for questions if there is an awkward silence. Once this discussion session ends the deliberation and the Q&A groups will answer the same post-test as the information packet group, but it will also contain a battery of questions about how the conversations went for later analysis.

q19.value: 300 (100 per treatment group: deliberative, Q&A, and information packet)

attributes.title: Seizing and Freezing: Inflexibility During Cyber Conflict

q1.value: Seizing and Freezing: Inflexibility During Cyber Conflict

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: The objective of the experiment is to test whether cyber operations evoke the seizing and freezing phenomena among decision-makers. With an increase in the use of cyber operations in the context of salient and enduring disputes between rivals, it becomes critical to understand whether or not biases contribute to the formation of judgement. In order to test this, the study utilizes Internet-based survey experiments in order to explore the possible role of seizing and freezing. The study provides a theoretical contribution by shifting the discussion of cyber security towards the individual/cognitive level. Methodologically, the use of experiments in cyber security is rare. Moreover, the study uses topic modelling in order to provide greater depth in understanding this phenomenon.

q16.value: H1: Decision-makers are likely to seize on cues when faced with cyber operations that appear to originate from an established rival. H2: Decision-makers are likely to freeze on previous judgements in the face of disconfirmatory evidence when faced with cyber operations that appear to originate from an established rival. H3: Past belligerent action in the physical domain increases the strength of the seizing and freezing phenomena. H4: Greater risk tolerance decreases the strength of the seizing and freezing phenomena. H5: Greater domain knowledge decreases the strength of the seizing and freezing phenomena.

q17.value: These will be tested using an Internet-based between-group survey experiment. The results of the experiment will then be analyzed using Generalized Linear Models and Topic Modelling.
